ContextualTheologies
New Contextual Theologies Emerge to Describe Faith in Light of Human Experience
Period: !!smallcaps|ad!! 1950s–Present
Description: As Christianity became a global faith, theologies emerged from the perspective of various people groups, especially among those in the Global South.

Summary: The latter half of the twentieth century saw the explosive growth of the global church due in part to the successes of the missionary movement of the nineteenth century, which sent Western missionaries---and Western culture---to the non-Western world.
Within the next century, colonialism was coming to an end and nationalism was on the rise, leading to a decline in Western influence in the Global South.
Indigenous expressions of Christianity flourished as  Christians sought to contextualize theology by taking into account their own human experience within a particular history and culture.
A variety of contextual theologies developed as indigenous Christians went about the work of theology.
Key Developments
Missionaries from North America and Europe exported Western culture to non-Western people groups (late 1700s–early 1900s).

Missionaries and theologians began applying the indigenous principle to their work to help develop indigenous churches that were reflective of the culture, language, and history of the people (1900s).
Contextual theologies emerged among various people groups to address specific cultural experiences and contexts (mid-1900s–2022).
Liberation theologies developed among oppressed and marginalized people groups who sought to interpret the gospel and Scripture within their social, political, and economic context (1968–2022).
Key People
African Theologians

John S. Mbiti (b. 1931): Kenyan Anglican theologian and "father of modern African theology"; author of African Religions and Philosophy and Introduction to African Religion, which addresses the beliefs and traditional religion of the African continent.

Mercy Amba Oduyoye (b. October 21, 1934): Ghanian Methodist womanist theologian; director of the Institute of African Women in Religion and Culture at Trinity Theological Seminary in Ghana; founder of the Circle of Concerned African Women Theologians; author of Introducing African Women's Theology, which describes the context and methodology of Christian theology by African women.
Asian Theologians

Shoki Coe (August 20, 1914–October 28, 1988): Taiwanese Presbyterian minister and theologian; director of the Theological Education Fund of the World Council of Churches; he coined the phrase "contextualizing theology" when referring to the development of local theologies.

Kwok Pui-lan (b. 1952): Chinese feminist and postcolonial theologian; she studied at Harvard University and taught at Candler School of Theology; converted to Anglicanism from Chinese folk religion; author of Introducing Asian Feminist Theology.
Black Liberation Theologians

James Hal Cone (August 5, 1938–April 28, 2018): Black American theologian; he developed Black theology and Black liberation theology; taught at Union Theological Seminary, Yale Divinity School, Princeton, the University of Paris, and Dartmouth College; author of Black Theology and Black Power; he was influenced by Karl Barth and wrote about his theology in his PhD thesis, The Doctrine of Man in the Theology of Karl Barth.

Cornel West (b. June 2, 1953): Black American philosopher, professor, civil rights activist, and theologian; he taught at Union Theological Seminary; adherent of Black liberation theology; author of Black Theology and Marxist Thought and Race Matters.
Feminist Theologians

Mary Daly (October 16, 1928–January 3, 2010): American Irish Catholic theologian and radical feminist scholar; she taught at the Jesuit school Boston College; adherent of feminist theology; author of The Church and the Second Sex; she eventually left the church.
Rosemary Radford Ruether (b. November 2, 1936): American feminist scholar and Roman Catholic theologian; advocate for women's ordination; author of Sexism and God-Talk: Toward a Feminist Theology.

Elisabeth Schüssler Fiorenza (b. April 17, 1938): German Catholic feminist theologian; she teaches at Harvard Divinity School; co-founder and editor of the Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion; author of In Memory of Her, which is a reconstruction of early Christianity and its relationship to women, and But She Said: Faithful Practices of Biblical Interpretation, which develops feminist biblical interpretations.
Latin American Theologians
Gustavo Gutiérrez (b. June 1, 1928: Peruvian Catholic priest; founder of liberation theology; author of Theology of Liberation.

María Pilar Aquino (b. March 6, 1956): Mexican Catholic feminist theologian; Research Professor of Theology and Religious Studies at the University of San Diego; author of Our Cry for Life: Feminist Theology from Latin America, which develops a feminist theology within the context of the poverty, oppression, and liberation of Latin American women.
Western Theologians

Stephen Bevans (b. July 14, 1944): American Roman Catholic priest, missiologist, and theologian; Professor of Mission and Culture, Emeritus at Catholic Theological Union; former president of the American Society of Missiology; member of the World Council of Churches' Commission on World Mission and Evangelism; author of Models of Contextual Theology, which argues that all theology is contextual and identifies models of contextual theology.
Womanist Theologians

Delores S. Williams (b. 1937): Black American Presbyterian theologian; Paul Tillich Professor of Theology and Culture, Emerita at Union Theological Seminary; developed womanist theology; author of Sisters in the Wilderness: The Challenge of Womanist God-Talk, which helped establish Black American womanist theology.
Systematic Theologies
Sexism and God-Talk: Toward a Feminist Theology (Rosemary Radford Ruether, 1983): a critique of patriarchal theology and a systematic approach to feminist theology.
Treatises
The Church and the Second Sex (Mary Daly, 1968): a critique of sexism within the Christian tradition and Catholic theology and praxis.
African Religions and Philosophy (John Mbiti, 1969): a survey of traditional African religions and worldviews.

A Theology of Liberation (Gustavo Gutiérrez, 1973): articulates liberation theology which emphasizes social, economic, and political liberation of the poor and oppressed; definitive text on Latin American liberation theology.
But She Said: Feminist Practices of Biblical Interpretation (Elizabeth Schüssler Fiorenza, 1992): develops feminist biblical interpretations and hermeneutics.

Black Theology and Black Power (James H. Cone, 1969): addresses the relationship between Black and white people in America; develops a Black theology that attempts to reconcile Black power, which Cone describes as "black freedom, black self-determination, wherein black people no longer view themselves as without human dignity,"[^1] with Christianity.
Models of Contextual Theology (Stephen B. Bevan, 1992): argues that all theology is contextual and identifies models of contextual theology; revised in 2002 with an additional sixth model.
Our Cry for Life: Feminist Theology from Latin America (María Pilar Aquino, 1993): develops a feminist theology within the context of the poverty, oppression, and liberation of Latin American women.
Sisters in the Wilderness: The Challenge of Womanist God-Talk (Delores S. Williams, 1993): develops a womanist theology within the context of Black American women's experiences.
Introducing Asian Feminist Theology (Kwok Pui-lan, 2000): a survey of the social, political, and cultural experiences of Asian women and introduction to Asian feminist theology.

Key Events
1945–1960: Many Asian and African countries struggle for and achieve their independence.
1954–1968: Civil Rights Movement in America seeks to end racial segregation and discrimination.
1960s–1970s: Second-wave feminism seeks to establish equality for women and is generally critical of patriarchal society.
1968: Liberation theology begins at the second Latin American Bishops' Conference in Medellín, Colombia.
1969: Black Theology and Black Power by James H. Cone is published.
1972: Shoki Coe coins the phrase "contextualizing theology."
1973: A Theology of Liberation by Gustavo Gutierrez is published.
1980s: Womanist theology emerges in North America.
1990s: Third-wave feminism encourages intersectionality and opposed gender stereotypes.
2010s: Fourth-wave feminism advocates for empowering women and intersectionality.
Key Places
Africa is where African theology developed; many countries gained independence during the 1950s –1980s.
Asia is where Asian theologies developed; many countries gained independence during the 1940s–1990s.
Latin America is where liberation theology developed; it achieved independence in the nineteenth century, followed by periods of revolution, oppressive regimes, and democracy.

North America is where Black theology and feminist theology developed; segregation was enforced here throughout the Jim Crow era followed by the Civil Rights Movement; the feminist movement took place here in 1848, with additional waves in the late 1900s–early 2000s.
Key Concepts
African theology emerged in the twentieth century to describe the Christian faith from the experience of Africans.
Asian Theology emerged in the twentieth century to describe the Christian faith from the experience of Asians.
Black Theology developed in the 1960s in North America during the Civil Rights Movement to describe the Christian faith from the experience of Black Americans.
Contextual theologies developed as Christianity spread across the globe to describe the Christian faith from the human experiences of non-Western peoples.
Feminist Theology emerged out of the feminist movement in North America in the 1970s to describe the Christian faith from the experience of women.
Liberation Theology emerged in the 1960s in Latin America out of Roman Catholicism to describe the Christian faith in light of the experiences of those living in  poverty.

Womanist Theology emerged in the 1980s to describe the Christian faith in light of the experiences of Black American women; the term "womanist" was coined by author and social activist Alice Walker in In Search of Our Mother's Gardens.
